result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Matthew C Mulac

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Matthew C Mulac in court, in custody.  Attorney Brian Michael Borkowicz in court for Matthew C Mulac.  Prosecuting attorney Jeanette Kara Corbett in court for the State of Wisconsin. Counsel's first appearance. Court recites history of case and questions State.  Illinois is trying to obtain Governor's Warrant; adj requested.  Counsel indicates def has sentencing in Marinette Co on 11-22-22; counsel to advise clerk of def's whereabouts if def shall appear by video for next hearing.
Hearing scheduled for November 28, 2022 at 01:15 pm.

Defendant Matthew C Mulac in court, in custody.  Attorney Timothy Drewa appeared by video for Matthew C Mulac.  Attorney Mark David Bensen in court for State of Wisconsin. Def given complaint, advised of charges, penalties and rights, and probable cause found. Court informs Defendant of DNA expungement rights. Court questions def. Def does not waive extradition and makes demand for governors warrant. Def has case pending in Br I (21CF361). Court order $2500 cash bond.
Hearing scheduled for September 28, 2022 at 08:15 am.
